Meta.Scope: Travel guide worlds only (enough on-screen canon to support location, appearance, geography, cities, inhabitants, visitation/tourism, and weather).
Notes: All fields are designed for travel-guide readability; deeper lore can be appended later without changing structure.
Location quadrants can be ambiguous in canon charts; use Location.QuadrantNotes when needed.

Planets.Name: Earth

Location.QuadrantNotes: Earth is within Sector 001; the Sol system sits near the Alpha/Beta border in some charts, but is generally treated as Alpha.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Federation Standard is widely used; most visitors will not have communication issues.

Planets.TravelSummary: Earth is the political and cultural heart of the United Federation of Planets for much of the 22nd–25th centuries, and the administrative center of Starfleet. Visitors can comfortably mix historic landmarks, restored natural spaces, and modern Federation civic districts—especially around San Francisco Bay and Paris—while enjoying famously diverse food, arts, and museums.

Appearance.GeneralLook: A blue-and-green world with extensive oceans, varied continents, and dense urban corridors balanced by preserved and restored natural environments.
FromOrbit: High-density orbital traffic and infrastructure during major Starfleet periods
Major approach lanes into the Sol system and Earth orbit are tightly controlled during alerts
NotableLandscapes: San Francisco Bay area and coastline
European river valleys and historic urban cores
Rural preserves and heritage sites tied to First Contact history
SurfaceNotes: Civic architecture ranges from preserved pre-warp landmarks to sleek Federation-era public buildings.
Many locations prominently integrate water features, parks, and pedestrian spaces.

Biomes.Name: Coastal temperate
Biomes.Notes: Common along many major port cities and Starfleet-era coastal hubs.

Biomes.Name: Mediterranean
Biomes.Notes: Typical of California’s coastal belt; fog and cool evenings are common near the Bay.

Biomes.Name: Temperate continental
Biomes.Notes: Large seasonal swing inland across many northern landmasses.

Biomes.Name: Subtropical
Biomes.Notes: Humid summers and storm seasons in some coastal lowlands.

Landmarks.Name: Starfleet Headquarters
VisitorNotes: Public access varies by era and security posture.
Viewing areas can offer iconic skyline and bay vistas.

Landmarks.Name: Starfleet Academy (Earth campus)
VisitorNotes: A major destination for tours, ceremonies, and alumni events.
Some grounds and exhibits may be restricted during cadet training cycles.

Landmarks.Name: Golden Gate Bridge
VisitorNotes: Frequently visible in Starfleet-era shoreline panoramas.
Best enjoyed on foot or via scenic transit routes along the Bay.

Landmarks.Name: Office of the Federation President (Paris)
VisitorNotes: A high-security district—plan for screenings, cordons, and restricted airspace when delegations are present.

Landmarks.Name: Eiffel Tower
VisitorNotes: A long-standing symbol of Paris; viewpoints and cafés nearby are popular with travelers.

Landmarks.Name: First Contact heritage sites (Bozeman region)
VisitorNotes: Key pilgrimage for history enthusiasts; guided tours often focus on the Phoenix program and early warp era.

Landmarks.Name: San Francisco Fleet Yards / Spacedock approach zones
Landmarks.CityOrRegion: San Francisco Bay area / Earth orbit
VisitorNotes: Observation is often possible from designated public platforms, but access to controlled zones requires authorization.

Cities.Name: San Francisco
Cities.LocalVibe: Cosmopolitan waterfront city with strong Federation civic identity.

Cities.Name: Paris
Cities.Role: Federation executive district (President’s office) and cultural capital
Highlights: Historic architecture alongside modern Federation buildings
Cities.LocalVibe: Historic European metropolis with prestige institutions and ceremonial spaces.

Cities.Name: New Orleans
Cities.LocalVibe: Food, music, and tradition-forward city with a relaxed rhythm.

Cities.Name: London
Cities.LocalVibe: Dense cultural heritage blended with modern urban life.

Primary.Notes: Earth’s dominant native population; society is strongly Federation-integrated.

NotableCultures.Name: United Earth civic culture
NotableCultures.Notes: Visitors will find strong norms around pluralism, diplomacy, and public education.

NotableCultures.Name: Starfleet community presence
NotableCultures.Notes: Academy cadets, officers, and visiting crews shape local rhythms near major facilities.

VisitorEtiquette: Expect security screening and identity checks near Starfleet and Federation facilities.
Avoid restricted shoreline and airspace zones around major orbital-interface sites during alerts.
Respect memorials and historic sites—many are treated as solemn civic spaces.
Food culture is wide-ranging; reservations are common for renowned family restaurants.

Weather.Seasonality: Standard seasonal cycles in many regions; local microclimates are common near coasts and major bays.

Hazards.Notes: Local storms can delay shuttle schedules and outdoor events; buffer time is recommended.
During major political or military events, travel corridors may change rapidly.

TopAttractions.Name: Starfleet waterfront district tours
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Iconic Federation-era vistas and civic architecture.

TopAttractions.Name: Academy ceremonies and public exhibits
TopAttractions.WhyGo: A front-row view into Starfleet tradition and training culture.

TopAttractions.Name: Paris civic + historic walk
TopAttractions.WhyGo: A blend of deep history and Federation executive geography.

TopAttractions.Name: First Contact history circuit
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Museums and guided routes focused on the warp era and early interstellar diplomacy.

Activities: Museum and archive days (Federation history, warp-era exhibits)
Bayfront walks and scenic transit loops
Cuisine trips spanning regional Earth traditions
Seasonal festivals and cultural performances
Restrictions: No-fly / no-drone zones near Starfleet and Federation executive areas during high security.
Certain Academy areas are cadet-only and may be closed during training and examinations.
SafetyNotes: Check current advisories for Sol system traffic controls before arrival.
Carry ID and travel authorization if planning visits near major government campuses.
During major anniversaries and ceremonies, crowds can be dense—plan transit accordingly.

Entry: Federation standard customs procedures (varies by era and political context).
Visitors approaching through Earth orbit may be routed via controlled corridors, especially during alerts.
LocalTransport: High-capacity urban transit networks in major cities
Shuttles and licensed air/space traffic near orbital-interface zones
Transporter use depends on local infrastructure and security rules
CurrencyNotes: Visitors should expect largely cashless exchange; carry travel credentials compatible with local services.
Lodging: City-center hotels and guest facilities near major cultural districts
Outlying eco-lodges and heritage inns near historic sites
Communications: Dense communications infrastructure; universal translator support is generally unnecessary for Standard speech, but available for visitors.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan
Key.Notes: Starfleet Academy is explicitly identified on Earth in San Francisco.
Federation President’s office is located in Paris; Earth security posture becomes a central theme.
First Contact history in the Bozeman region is central; Earth is a strategic target.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home
Key.Notes: Earth experiences oceanic ecological crisis driven by an alien probe.
Earth (France) is depicted as a personal, cultural home base for Starfleet officers.
Sol system security and orbital threat scenarios are central to the plot.

Planets.Name: Vulcan

Location.QuadrantNotes: Canon charts and references vary; modern on-screen star charts often place the Vulcan system in Beta. Treat as near the Alpha/Beta border in many practical travel contexts.

SkyNotes: Vulcan has no natural moons in canon references; it forms a binary pair with the companion planet T'Khut, which can be prominent in the sky under clear conditions.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visitors commonly rely on shipboard chronometers and civic time beacons.

Planets.TravelSummary: Vulcan is a world of austere beauty—deserts, volcanic badlands, and sacred mountains tied to Surak’s legacy. Tourism centers on cultural immersion: meditation retreats, historical sanctuaries, and guided routes through cities built to endure harsh climates. It’s rewarding, but requires preparation for heat, dust, and strict local etiquette around privacy and emotional control.

Appearance.GeneralLook: An arid world with broad deserts, volcanic regions, and rugged mountain landmarks; architecture often emphasizes shaded courtyards, stone, and heat-resilient design.
FromOrbit: Desert belts and highland contours are visually dominant
The Vulcan system’s companion world relationships are a notable feature of local cartography
SurfaceNotes: Visitors commonly report intense light, rapid dehydration risk, and strong day–night comfort swings.
Some wilderness zones can interfere with technology and require analog navigation backups.

Biomes.Name: Hot desert
Biomes.Notes: Large stretches of exposed sand and rock; travel is best at dawn/dusk with proper seals.

Biomes.Name: Volcanic desert / badlands
Biomes.Notes: Harsh terrain with geomagnetic instability and electrical storm risk in certain regions.

Biomes.Name: Highlands and mountain corridors
Biomes.Notes: Sacred routes, monasteries, and pilgrimage trails; temperatures can vary sharply with elevation.

Landmarks.Name: Vulcan's Forge
VisitorNotes: Known for electrical sandstorms and geomagnetic interference that can disrupt scanners and transporters in certain eras.
Guided excursions are strongly recommended; permits may be required depending on local governance.

Landmarks.Name: Mount Seleya
VisitorNotes: Major spiritual destination; temple structures and ceremonial spaces are present in some eras.
Respect access rules, silence protocols, and restricted ceremonial zones.

Landmarks.Name: T'Karath Sanctuary (region)
VisitorNotes: Associated with Surak-era legacy and key cultural events; access may be limited to authorized visitors.

Landmarks.Name: Hall of Ancient Thought (Mount Seleya complex)
VisitorNotes: A destination for scholars and pilgrims; follow guidance about photography, recording, and artifact proximity.

Cities.Name: ShiKahr
Cities.Role: Major city near the edge of the Forge
Highlights: Desert-edge architecture optimized for shade and heat control
Cultural residences associated with prominent Vulcan families in some eras
Cities.LocalVibe: Orderly, quiet, and tradition-forward; visitors are expected to be self-contained and respectful.

Cities.Name: Gol
Highlights: Referenced in Vulcan historical accounts and cautionary tales
Often approached as an educational stop rather than a leisure destination
Cities.LocalVibe: Austere heritage site—visit via curator-led routes if available.

Primary.Notes: Native population; cultural norms emphasize logic, privacy, and emotional discipline.

NotableCultures.Name: Surakian tradition
NotableCultures.Notes: Pilgrimage, scholarship, and meditation are central to many visitor experiences.

NotableCultures.Name: Scientific institutions
NotableCultures.Notes: Academic culture is prominent; lectures and symposiums can be major tourist draws in some eras.

VisitorEtiquette: Keep your voice low; emotional displays are often considered disruptive in public spaces.
Avoid unsolicited physical contact; ask permission before assisting someone physically.
Never attempt or request a mind meld casually—consent and cultural context are critical.
Dress for sun and dust: breathable layers, eye protection, and sealed footwear are standard.
Carry water and electrolyte supplementation for outdoor travel; dehydration can escalate quickly.
Follow shrine and sanctuary rules precisely: silence zones, footwear policies, and restricted steps are common.
Do not treat sacred symbols (e.g., IDIC iconography) as casual merchandise in solemn spaces.
When invited into a home, wait for explicit guidance on seating, food, and conversation topics.
Photography/recording may be restricted in religious and academic areas—ask before capturing images.
On guided treks, stay with your group; terrain and stormfronts can shift quickly.

Weather.ClimateType: Arid to desert; localized extreme environments
Weather.Seasonality: Heat dominance with significant day–night swings; seasonal variation exists but is less visually dramatic than on Earth.

Hazards.Notes: Fast-moving storms with blinding sand and lightning-like electrical discharges; can last hours to days and require sealed shelter.
Can interfere with scanners, communicators, and transporters (especially in 22nd-century tech contexts).
Primary day-trip risk for offworld visitors; plan shade breaks and carry water beyond Earth-normal expectations.

TopAttractions.Name: Pilgrimage and meditation itineraries
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Direct immersion in Surak-era cultural legacy and modern contemplative practice.

TopAttractions.Name: City cultural walks (ShiKahr region)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Desert-adapted urban design and curated heritage routes near the Forge boundary.

TopAttractions.Name: Sacred mountain excursions (Mount Seleya)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: One of the most iconic spiritual destinations with well-known ceremonial associations.

TopAttractions.Name: Scholarly events and public lectures
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Vulcan academic culture can be a highlight for science-forward travelers.

Activities: Guided desert treks (non-Forge routes recommended for casual visitors)
Museum and archive visits focused on Vulcan history and philosophy
Meditation retreats and cultural workshops (by invitation or registration)
Night-sky viewing when conditions allow (companion planet visibility can be striking)
Restrictions: Forge-area travel may require permits, guides, and approved equipment checklists.
Sacred and governmental facilities may restrict offworld visitors during political tension or ceremonial periods.
Some rites and trials are not tourist events; do not attempt participation without formal invitation.
SafetyNotes: Never enter the Forge without sealed shelter options and a guide familiar with storm behavior.
Carry redundant navigation and communications options; some terrain can disrupt instruments.
Plan arrivals and departures around heat peaks; dawn/dusk itineraries reduce risk.
Respect local authority immediately during advisories—Vulcan enforcement is typically strict and procedural.

Entry: Expect strict customs and documentation checks; Vulcan authorities prioritize order and clarity.
Visitors may be required to declare scientific equipment, recording devices, and medical supplies.
LocalTransport: Urban transit and regulated shuttles near major cities
Licensed ground vehicles for desert routes
Guided convoys for wilderness itineraries in higher-risk regions
CurrencyNotes: Visitors should plan for credential-based payment systems and pre-authorized travel accounts.
Lodging: Quiet guest facilities with strong privacy norms near cities
Retreat-style accommodations for meditation and study travelers
Communications: Universal translator is useful for cultural nuance, but many Vulcans are fluent in Federation Standard in Federation-era contexts.

Key.Notes: Vulcan surface and cultural rites are central.
ShiKahr and desert-edge travel context; companion-world sky imagery is featured.
Forge hazards, sacred routes, and political-cultural conflicts are explored in depth.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock
Key.Notes: Mount Seleya ceremonial site (fal-tor-pan) is depicted.
Vulcan cultural and philosophical context is central to Spock’s arc.
Modern-era Vulcan system display canonizes T'Khut and system details.

Planets.Name: Ferenginar

Location.QuadrantNotes: Seat of the Ferengi Alliance; on-screen cartography and references place Ferenginar in the Alpha Quadrant. It is described on a tactical/okudagram context as approximately sixty light years from the Bajoran system.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Ferengi language is common in domestic contexts; Federation Standard is widely understood in trade-facing areas.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visitors typically rely on shipboard chronometers and civic time beacons for appointments.

Planets.TravelSummary: Ferenginar is a rain-soaked commercial capital where weather, architecture, and etiquette revolve around staying dry and doing business. Visitors come for the Sacred Marketplace, museums dedicated to Ferengi deal-craft, and a front-row look at the Alliance’s profit-driven civic culture—while learning quickly that climate, crowds, and opportunistic sales tactics shape every outing.

Appearance.GeneralLook: A humid, overcast world of slick streets, domed structures, and market districts built to function through near-constant rainfall. City vistas emphasize layered canopies, covered walkways, and vertical civic spires rising above a dense marketplace.
FromOrbit: Persistent cloud cover and broad weather systems are common
Approach traffic concentrates around major commercial hubs and government districts
NotableLandscapes: River channels and drainage corridors carrying heavy runoff
Dense urban districts clustered around major marketplaces
SurfaceNotes: Expect wet ground conditions almost everywhere—non-slip footwear and sealed bags are standard.
Many high-traffic civic areas are covered or partially enclosed to keep commerce moving during downpours.

Biomes.Name: Wetlands and swamp
Biomes.Notes: Humid lowlands, saturated soil, and standing water are common; vegetation is often described as damp and prone to rot in persistent rain.

Biomes.Name: Rainy urban lowlands
Biomes.Notes: Cities are designed around drainage, covered walkways, and domed market spaces to mitigate constant precipitation.

Landmarks.Name: Sacred Marketplace
VisitorNotes: The central market district and symbolic heart of Ferengi commerce.
High-density crowds; keep valuables secured and arrange meetups at fixed landmarks.

Landmarks.Name: Tower of Commerce
VisitorNotes: Seat of the Grand Nagus and Alliance governance; also houses Ferengi Commerce Authority offices.
Public access varies by political climate and security posture; expect screening and restricted floors.
Viewing areas offer iconic skyline shots of the market district in the rain.

Landmarks.Name: Museum of Bribery
VisitorNotes: A culture-focused museum highlighting Ferengi history of influence, incentives, and negotiation norms.
Treat exhibits as cultural education; do not interpret displays as guidance for illegal activity offworld.

Landmarks.Name: Museum of Gambling
VisitorNotes: Showcases Ferengi gaming culture and risk-taking traditions.
Use reputable venues for any sanctioned games; avoid unlicensed street offers.

Landmarks.Name: Museum of Haggling
VisitorNotes: Practical history of Ferengi bargaining styles; useful primer before shopping.
Some tours include staged negotiations—confirm prices and terms in advance.

Landmarks.Name: Ferengi Hall of Fame
VisitorNotes: Profiles notable Ferengi figures and landmark business achievements.
Guided tours often frame events through the Rules of Acquisition.

Landmarks.Name: Ferengi Center for Forged Arts
VisitorNotes: Art venue emphasizing craftsmanship and commerce; verify authenticity certificates for purchases.

Landmarks.Name: Ferenginar Historic Public Library
VisitorNotes: Archive access may require registration; keep equipment protected from humidity.

Landmarks.Name: Dominion War Memorial
VisitorNotes: A solemn civic site; observe quiet conduct and local protocols.

Landmarks.Name: Nagal Residence
VisitorNotes: Associated with the Grand Nagus; public viewing is typically limited to designated areas or special events.

Cities.Name: Capital City (Sacred Marketplace district)
Highlights: Museums dedicated to Ferengi trade culture
Cities.LocalVibe: Crowded, deal-driven, and perpetually damp—fast-paced commerce under awnings, domes, and covered arcades.

Primary.Notes: A mercantile culture where status is tied to profit, contracts, and negotiation skill.

NotableCultures.Name: Rules of Acquisition civic culture
NotableCultures.Notes: Business norms and social etiquette are often framed through the Rules of Acquisition and the pursuit of profit.

NotableCultures.Name: Ferengi Commerce Authority presence
NotableCultures.Notes: Regulatory enforcement exists alongside widespread graft and aggressive sales tactics; visitors should stick to reputable vendors.

VisitorEtiquette: Assume every price is negotiable unless explicitly posted as fixed—haggling is expected in many contexts.
Get agreements in writing (or recorded contract form) before exchanging funds or goods—clarify fees, delivery, and refunds.
Avoid insulting someone’s business acumen; negotiations are social contests as much as transactions.
Keep personal financial details private; targeted upselling and ‘exclusive’ offers are common.
Respect local laws and social norms, including gender and dress restrictions in specific venues—do not assume offworld norms apply.
Be cautious with gifts and ‘samples’—confirm whether they’re free before accepting.

Weather.Seasonality: Rain is described as persistent and pervasive; local weather variation is more about intensity and storm bursts than clear dry seasons.

Hazards.Notes: Sudden downpours can flood low streets and disrupt surface travel; plan sheltered routes and flexible timing.
Electronics, paper goods, and clothing can degrade quickly without sealing and drying routines.
Polished stone, metal walkways, and market tiles can be slick; non-slip footwear is strongly recommended.

TravelGear: Sealed outer layer or poncho; quick-dry clothing
Waterproof bags for comm devices and padds
Anti-fog eye protection in heavy humidity

TopAttractions.Name: Sacred Marketplace day pass
TopAttractions.WhyGo: The core Ferengi shopping and negotiation experience under domes and awnings.

TopAttractions.Name: Tower of Commerce observation + civic tour
TopAttractions.WhyGo: The symbolic and governmental center of the Alliance, dominated by the Grand Nagus’ palace complex.

TopAttractions.Name: Ferengi museums circuit
TopAttractions.WhyGo: A guided route through museums of bribery, gambling, and haggling—ideal for understanding local deal culture.

TopAttractions.Name: Deal-craft workshops (licensed)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Structured lessons in bargaining etiquette and contract basics for offworld visitors.

Activities: Market crawls with a vetted guide (price-checking and safe vendor lists)
Cultural lectures on the Rules of Acquisition and Ferengi economic history
Museum days (trade, gambling, negotiation exhibits)
Food and beverage tastings with humidity-resistant packaging
Restrictions: Government and FCA areas in the Tower of Commerce may be closed without notice during investigations or political shifts.
Some venues enforce local social norms strictly; verify dress and conduct rules before arrival.
SafetyNotes: Avoid ‘too-good-to-be-true’ offers—use licensed vendors and confirm authentication for high-value items.
Do not carry all funds or latinum in one place; use secure accounts and incremental transfers.
If a deal becomes pressured or time-limited, walk away—high-pressure tactics are common in tourist zones.

Entry: Expect customs declarations focused on trade goods, valuables, and commercial equipment.
Business-visas or transaction permits may be required for high-value buying/selling depending on era and local policy.
LocalTransport: Covered pedestrian corridors within major market districts
Licensed ground transport and shuttle links between civic zones
Transit routes may reroute around flooded streets during heavy rain bursts
CurrencyNotes: Latinums and contract-based credit arrangements are common in Ferengi trade contexts; confirm exchange and fee schedules in writing.
Lodging: Business hotels and guest houses near major market hubs
Humidity-managed suites (recommended for visitors with sensitive equipment or attire)
Communications: Universal translator is helpful for negotiations and contract nuance; consider using verified legal translation services for major purchases.

Key.Notes: First on-screen depiction of Ferenginar; rain-soaked homeworld context.
Tower of Commerce named and described; Nagus’ palace complex.
References to the Tower of Commerce and FCA; harsh enforcement practices are mentioned.
Tower of Commerce offices and Ferengi political/commercial life.
Ferenginar described as torrential rain, dampness, rotting vegetation, and rivers of muck.
Ferengi Alliance politics and Ferengi homeworld context referenced.

Planets.Name: Risa

Location.QuadrantNotes: Federation resort world in the Epsilon Ceti system; commonly cited as approximately 93 light-years from Sol.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Federation Standard is widely used in tourism districts; local language and customs remain prominent in cultural settings.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; resort schedules and Starfleet visitors commonly operate on shipboard chronometers.

Planets.TravelSummary: Risa is the Federation’s best-known vacation world: warm surf, lush gardens, and a famously welcoming culture built around relaxation, consent-forward romance, and curated leisure. Its paradise weather is maintained by planet-wide systems, so the experience is intentionally consistent—sun, breezes, and comfortable temperatures—unless a system disruption or political incident forces the ‘real’ climate to break through.

Appearance.GeneralLook: A tropical resort planet of beaches, lagoons, palm-lined promenades, and low-rise leisure architecture—often open-air, shaded, and designed to feel effortless and indulgent.
FromOrbit: Bright ocean expanses with frequent cloud bands
Approach routes are dense during peak travel seasons
Tourism hubs produce distinctive night-side illumination clusters around resort belts
NotableLandscapes: White-sand beaches and shallow coastal shelves
Warm lagoons and reef-like shallows near resort districts
Garden complexes and landscaped courtyards integrated into hotels and villas
SurfaceNotes: Public spaces prioritize walkability: covered paths, misting arches, and shaded plazas.
Dress norms are relaxed in resort zones, but guests should still respect posted rules for sacred/cultural sites.

Biomes.Name: Tropical coast
Biomes.Notes: Beaches, palms, warm surf, and high UV—plan sun protection even in ‘perfect weather’ conditions.

Biomes.Name: Lagoon and garden districts
Biomes.Notes: Landscaped water features and curated greenery dominate near major resorts.

Landmarks.Name: Tembiti Lagoon (Resort complex)
VisitorNotes: A flagship lagoon-side destination frequently used for offworlder vacations.
Check local event calendars for festivals, mixers, and cultural nights.

Landmarks.Name: Shore Leave Promenade
VisitorNotes: Main pedestrian artery lined with shops, clubs, and tour kiosks.
Prime spot for people-watching, day passes, and booking curated experiences.

Landmarks.Name: Horga'hn Plaza (Jamaharon district)
VisitorNotes: A social hub associated with Risian romance customs; expect playful symbolism and lots of flirtation.
Consent etiquette is essential—Risa’s openness does not mean anything is assumed.

Landmarks.Name: Weather Control Grid / Control Centers (restricted)
VisitorNotes: Not a tourist attraction; access is restricted.
System disruptions can dramatically change conditions—monitor advisories if you’re on multi-day excursions.

Cities.Name: Resort Belt (capital tourism district)
Cities.Role: Primary visitor zone and hospitality core
Highlights: High-capacity transit loops and concierge hubs
Cities.LocalVibe: Festive, relaxed, flirtatious, and service-forward—designed to make visitors forget they’re on a schedule.

Primary.Notes: A hospitality-forward culture with famously open attitudes toward pleasure, romance, and leisure—balanced by strong social rules around consent and respect.

NotableCultures.Name: Hospitality guild culture
NotableCultures.Notes: Tourism work is highly respected; many services are ritualized into ‘experiences’ rather than simple transactions.

NotableCultures.Name: Jamaharon tradition (symbolic courtship custom)
NotableCultures.Notes: Often referenced through the horga'hn statuette; treated playfully in resort zones but still grounded in local etiquette.

VisitorEtiquette: Consent-first: flirting is common, but never assume interest; follow clear verbal or behavioral cues.
If you accept an invitation, clarify expectations—Risians often treat communication as part of the experience.
Respect local symbols (including the horga'hn) and avoid using them to embarrass others.
Dress norms are relaxed, but resorts still post rules for dining, ceremonies, and formal events—follow them.
Don’t mock leisure culture; on Risa, relaxation is treated as a serious civic priority.

Weather.ClimateType: Tropical, artificially stabilized by planet-wide weather control (with supplemental seismic regulation in some eras).
Weather.Seasonality: Under normal operations, seasonality is intentionally muted to maintain near-constant ‘ideal’ vacation conditions; disruptions can restore storms and unstable patterns quickly.

Hazards.Notes: Can produce sudden heavy storms, rough seas, and travel delays; follow resort advisories and shelter guidance.
Sabotage or political unrest can cause localized outages and crowd surges—avoid restricted areas and keep to official routes.
Even with perfect weather, UV exposure can be intense; use protection and hydrate.

TravelGear: Light breathable clothing plus one dry layer for sudden storms
Comfort footwear for long promenade walks

TopAttractions.Name: Lagoon resort days
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Iconic Risa: warm water, shaded cabanas, and effortless service culture.

TopAttractions.Name: Shore Leave Promenade evenings
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Social nights, music, food, and spontaneous meetups with travelers from across Federation space.

TopAttractions.Name: Cultural ‘experience’ bookings
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Guided leisure events designed by Risians—dance, cuisine, crafts, and romance-themed festivals.

TopAttractions.Name: Private villa retreats
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Quiet, curated relaxation away from peak promenade crowds.

Activities: Beach and lagoon swimming
Sailing and small-craft excursions (conditions permitting)
Resort spa circuits and wellness programs
Nightlife: clubs, live music, and themed social events
Guided cultural tours focusing on Risian customs and hospitality traditions
Restrictions: Weather control and planetary infrastructure sites are restricted.
Some events have explicit participation rules; resorts may enforce conduct standards tightly to protect guests.
SafetyNotes: Use official booking channels—tourist zones can attract opportunistic scams and counterfeit ‘exclusive’ passes.
If storms hit, leave the water immediately and follow resort shelter instructions.
Set boundaries clearly; if someone ignores them, contact resort security—Risa prioritizes guest safety and consent.

Entry: Federation-friendly arrival procedures; peak seasons can produce heavy traffic and longer berth allocation times.
Resorts often handle customs/registration through pre-arrival concierge workflows.
LocalTransport: Resort transit loops (shuttles, trams, and pedestrian corridors)
Transporter use varies by venue and local security posture
CurrencyNotes: Resort packages and Federation-standard payments are common; confirm what’s included vs. premium add-ons before arrival.
Lodging: Lagoon resorts, beach hotels, and private villas
Quiet retreat properties away from main nightlife zones
Communications: Excellent tourism communications coverage; most visitors operate comfortably in Federation Standard with translator support for nuance.

Key.Notes: Introduces Risa as the Federation’s premier pleasure planet; resort culture and shore leave norms are central.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: DS9: Let He Who Is Without Sin...
Key.Notes: Explores resort politics, sabotage of weather systems, and Risa’s role as a cultural flashpoint for visitors.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: ENT: Two Days and Two Nights
Key.Notes: Early-era shore leave depiction; Risa as a destination for offworld travelers.

Planets.Name: Qo'noS

Location.QuadrantNotes: Qo'noS is located in the Qo'noS system within Klingon space (Sector 70 / the Qo'noS sector). It had one moon, Praxis, which was destroyed in 2293.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Klingon (tlhIngan Hol) is dominant; Federation Standard is understood in diplomatic, trade, and offworlder-facing contexts.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visitors often rely on shipboard chronometers when coordinating with offworld schedules.

Planets.TravelSummary: Qo'noS is the seat of Klingon power: a world where politics, honor, and public ritual intertwine in the shadow of the Great Hall. For visitors, it’s less a carefree destination and more a place to witness imperial ceremony, architecture built like fortresses, and a culture that expects confidence, clarity, and respect for rank. Travel is best planned around security rules, diplomatic climates, and regional conditions that can feel harsh compared to Federation resort worlds.

Appearance.GeneralLook: A rugged, imposing world often associated with green-tinged skies and dramatic, austere cityscapes—massive stone-and-metal structures, monumental civic halls, and streets designed for processions and guard presence as much as daily life.
FromOrbit: Approach corridors are tightly managed, with traffic patterns shaped by Klingon security and military priorities
Major population centers present dense night-side illumination clusters, with heavy emphasis around the capital region
NotableLandscapes: Extensive cave systems and subterranean networks
Rugged highlands and broad plains outside major urban centers
SurfaceNotes: Many civic buildings are designed for spectacle: grand entrances, wide courtyards, and intimidating vertical scale.
Expect visible security—uniformed guards, checkpoints, and restricted zones near government sites.

Biomes.Name: Volcanic zones and basaltic fields
Biomes.Notes: Volcanic features and lava-formed terrain are a recurring part of the planet’s portrayal; some regions connect to large subterranean systems.

Biomes.Name: Cave networks and subterranean complexes
Biomes.Notes: Described as a 'planet of caves' in some depictions, with long-dormant subterranean volcano systems and cavern spaces large enough to support significant activity.

Biomes.Name: Urban and industrial corridors (capital region)
Biomes.Notes: Capital-adjacent districts blend civic monumentalism with heavy infrastructure; conditions can feel harsh, especially during periods of political or environmental stress.

Landmarks.Name: First City
VisitorNotes: The imperial capital and the primary hub for government, ceremony, and major hearings.
Movement in and around civic cores is often controlled; keep identification and travel authorization readily available.

Landmarks.Name: Great Hall
VisitorNotes: Iconic Klingon seat of ceremony and political assembly, associated with the Klingon High Council.
Access is typically restricted; when permitted, visitors should expect formal conduct rules and tight security screening.

Landmarks.Name: Klingon High Council Chamber
VisitorNotes: A highly controlled interior zone linked to Klingon governance and major proceedings.
Photography/recording rules (if any) are set case-by-case—assume prohibited unless explicitly authorized.

Cities.Name: First City
Cities.Role: Imperial capital and primary civic center
Highlights: Monumental architecture and guarded civic plazas
Cities.LocalVibe: Intense, formal, and security-forward—public spaces feel ceremonial, with visible rank culture and tightly policed boundaries.

Primary.Notes: A warrior society where honor, reputation, and directness shape social life; public ritual and political allegiance are strongly tied to House and status.

NotableCultures.Name: Great House politics
NotableCultures.Notes: Major families (Houses) hold power, influence, and obligation networks; visitors should avoid casually taking sides in disputes.

NotableCultures.Name: Ritual honor culture
NotableCultures.Notes: Many interactions are framed through public respect, challenge etiquette, and visible confidence—ambiguity can be read as weakness or deception.

VisitorEtiquette: Use correct titles and names; show respect for rank and House affiliation when it is declared.
Be direct and keep promises—backing out of agreements can be treated as dishonorable.
Avoid public mockery or sarcasm about Klingon tradition; it can escalate quickly.
Do not touch weapons, ceremonial objects, or House insignia without permission.
Follow checkpoint instructions immediately; arguing with guards is a fast way to end your trip.
If invited to a ritual or ceremony, ask a local liaison about expected conduct beforehand.

Weather.ClimateType: Regionally variable; conditions are often portrayed as turbulent and capable of harsh swings depending on location and era.
Weather.Seasonality: Seasonal variation is treated as significant in some portrayals; visitors should plan for sudden changes and pack for both cool and warm conditions unless traveling with a local-season briefing.

Conditions: Overcast or green-tinged skies in some depictions

Hazards.Notes: Political events can lock down transit corridors and public squares with little notice; keep alternate routes and shelter options.
Avoid unescorted travel near vents, unstable rock, and restricted cavern systems.
In late-23rd-century contexts, the Praxis disaster created planet-wide environmental strain and heightened controls.

TravelGear: A formal outfit if attending civic events (as advised by your liaison)

TopAttractions.Name: First City civic panorama
TopAttractions.WhyGo: A rare look at Klingon monumental architecture and public ceremony (when observation zones are open).

TopAttractions.Name: Cultural halls and memorial spaces (permitted zones)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Klingon history is performed as much as recorded—guided visits can provide context for House symbols, oaths, and honor rites.

TopAttractions.Name: Approved cuisine and music venues
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Public houses and performance spaces can be welcoming if you respect etiquette and don’t treat tradition as a joke.

Activities: Guided city walks in authorized districts
Ceremony observation (when permitted)
Curated cultural briefings with a local liaison
Supervised excursions to geological viewpoints away from restricted zones
Restrictions: Government buildings and High Council-adjacent areas are frequently restricted to authorized visitors.
Security conditions can change rapidly based on House politics or imperial events.
SafetyNotes: Travel with a vetted liaison if you plan to visit civic centers—this is not a casual walk-up destination.
Avoid bartering with unauthorized agents offering 'Council access' or 'House introductions'.
If challenged or provoked, disengage and leave—do not escalate without local guidance.

Entry: Entry requirements vary with the Klingon Empire’s diplomatic posture; visitors may need sponsorship, permits, or escort arrangements.
Expect strict inspections for weapons, recording equipment, and contraband.
LocalTransport: Guarded transit corridors and checkpointed routes in capital districts
Ground transport and shuttle links between authorized zones
Access restrictions are common near ceremonial sites and government compounds
CurrencyNotes: Trade rules depend on era and local policy; confirm what exchanges are permitted before arrival.
Lodging: Guest quarters in authorized districts (often arranged through sponsors)
Communications: Translator support is strongly recommended for formal proceedings and legal terms; direct language is culturally preferred.

Key.Notes: First on-screen depiction of the Klingon homeworld; establishes the capital-city look and Great Hall context.
Qo'noS is central during the Klingon civil war period and High Council politics.
Returns to Qo'noS for Klingon legal and political stakes.
Qo'noS is referenced as a strategic destination early in the 22nd century.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: DIS: Will You Take My Hand?
Key.Notes: Features Qo'noS in the context of conflict and political transition.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country
Key.Notes: Praxis’ destruction drives an environmental and political crisis tied to Qo'noS.
